text:
From a distance,
This tiny snail looks like just a colored

dot in the water,
but under a microscope the reason for its

name, “sea butterfly” becomes clear.
The “foot” of this snail has become two

wings that propel it up and down the water
column.

Instead of paddling, the sea butterfly “flies”
by rotating its wings in a figure 8,

almost clapping them together at the top of
the stroke, to generate lift—just like a flying insect.
